Award.AwardTitle: Ab-Initio Molecular Dynamics: Novel Developments with Application to H Bonded Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Roberto Car of Princeton University is supported by an award from The Theory, Models and Computational Methods program to develop new theoretical and computational enhancements of ab-initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations with special focus on applications to water and hydrogen-bonded systems. The PI and his research group focus on a four-pronged strategy: (i) simulations based on more accurate electronic density functional with inclusion of dispersion forces will be made possible, (ii) the potential experienced by the protons participating in hydrogen bonds will be unearthed by utilizing a novel theoretical concept that allows unprecedented comparison of quantum simulations and deep inelastic neutron scattering data, including already performed and newly planned experiments, (iii) a new real space scheme will be implemented to compute core and valence electronic excitations with accurate many-body methods (e. g. the GW approximation and the Bethe-Salpeter equation) for systems with hundreds of atoms at selected snapshots of AIMD simulations, boosting comparison with experiments (X-rays, UV and optical spectra) and their interpretation, and (iv) the affinity of hydrophobic interfaces for water ions will be computed with thermodynamic integration techniques, advancing the understanding at the molecular level of processes of great scientific and technological relevance.

The project will contribute to the scientific infrastructure with new algorithms for molecular simulation and spectral calculation, which will be made available to the wider science and engineering community through the open software platforms Quantum Espresso and Car-Parrinello Molecular Dynamics. The educational component of this project is well integrated with the proposed research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Water, the most abundant liquid on earth, plays a key role in chemistry, biology, geology and the environmental sciences. The molecular origins of its unique properties have been the focus of intense study for decades and are still highly debated today. In this project we modeled water with ab-initio Molecular Dynamics (AIMD), an approach in which the forces on the atoms are calculated on the fly from the instantaneous ground state of the electrons within density functional theory (DFT). While largely successful in many systems, DFT faces severe challenges in water. In water, the molecular interactions result from a delicate balance between directional hydrogen bonds and nearly isotropic dispersion interactions, i.e. interactions that are significantly weaker than the chemical bonds for which standard DFT approximations work well.

 

We found that the hybrid functional PBE0 in combination with the Tkatchenko-Scheffler (TS) scheme for dispersion interactions works well for pressure-induced transitions in ice (B. Santra et al., Phys. Rev. Lett. 107, 185701 (2011)) and significantly improves the agreement of the simulated water structures with experimental x-ray and neutron diffraction data (R.A. Distasio et al., J. Chem. Phys. 141, 084502 (2014)). The most significant effect of PBE0-TS is a substantial reduction of the overstructuring of water observed in previous AIMD studies. This originates from two effects: (i) the better polarizability of the water molecule with the hybrid functional; (ii) the inclusion of dispersion interactions ignored in standard approximations.

 

Dispersion interactions are ubiquitous in nature. They are crucial not only in water but in general in all forms of soft matter, including biological matter, and are also essential to describe layer compounds, such as graphite, and nanostructure assemblies, such as nanotube bundles. The effective pairwise approximation of the TS scheme captures only part of the dispersion interactions. We developed a scheme to include higher order many-body contributions, showing that they are crucial for an accurate treatment of the conformational energies of biomolecules and of the binding of molecular crystals (A. Tkatchenko, et al. Phys. Rev. Lett. 108, 236402 (2012)).

 

Due to the light hydrogen mass, nuclear quantum effects (NQE) are significant in water. To treat these effects we used path integral (PI) AIMD, an approach in which a quantum system in equilibrium is modeled by a system of classical beads representing discretized Feynman paths. Because of quantum mechanics, the momentum distribution of the protons reflects their local environment. We formulated an efficient scheme to compute the momentum distribution (L. Lin et al., Phys. Rev. Lett. 105, 110602 (2011)) and predicted directional effects in ice (L. Lin et al., Phys. Rev. B 83, 2230302 (2011)). Moreover, we collaborated with a leading experimental group to extract the momentum distribution in hexagonal ice from deep inelastic neutron scattering (DINS) data (D. Flammini et al., J. Chem. Phys. 136, 024504 (2012)).

 

With PI-AIMD we studied proton tunneling in hydrogen bonds. In a typical hydrogen bond the proton is closer to the donor than to the acceptor molecule. A displacement of one proton from donor to acceptor side would create a pair of charged defects, hydronium (OH3+) and hydroxide (OH-), and would be energetically costly. However, in a network of bonds concerted displacements could occur by quantum tunneling without creating charged defects. We found that this happens in the pressure induced phase transition between two ice forms, ice VIII and ice VII (L. Lin, et al. J. Stat. Phys. 145, 365 (2011)). We showed that at sufficiently low temperature this transition is due to quantum tunneling and involves highly correlated proton motions that avoid the formation of charged defects.

 

X-ray absorption spectra (XAS) in water were interpreted with help of transition state DFT calculations in a way that implied a substantially larger disruption of the hydrogen bond network than suggested by diffraction and thermodynamic data. Using substantially more accurate calculations we obtained good agreement with experiment within the standard hydrogen bond picture (W. Chen, et al., Phys. Rev. Lett. 105, 017802 (2010)). In a subsequent study using configurations generated by PI-AIMD we showed that the spectral XAS features are strongly affected by NQE (L. Kong, et al. Phys. Rev. B 86, 134203 (2012)).

 

Three Ph. D. theses and one senior undergraduate thesis at Princeton University were based on the above work. Broader impact included contributions to scientific software, dissemination of knowledge nationally and internationally, and contributions to the Princeton REU program.
